Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Light Scattering Spectroscopy and Microscopy of Molecular Interactions at Biological Surfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Hai-Lung Dai of Temple University to use a newly developed, laser-based technique to measure how drug-like molecules adsorb and transport through biological cell membranes. The knowledge gained here is important for the advancement of fundamental research in life sciences. It is also highly beneficial to chemical biology and pharmaceutical sciences research by providing a method to determine the rates of drug transport through cell membranes. Students participating in this research are prepared with a wide range of expertise in interdisciplinary areas involving biology, chemistry, medicine and physics, and as such, for careers in fundamental biomedically related research in academia and industry. Professor Dai's laboratory will continue to provide research opportunities for undergraduate students and high/middle school science teachers.

In the proposed studies, nonlinear light scattering methods with their intrinsic surface sensitivity, and time-, frequency-, and spatial-resolution, are used to provide a molecular level description of how molecules interact with biological surfaces. This newly developed method will be applied in several areas including determining: 1) how molecular and membrane structures affect molecular transport though cell membranes; 2) how membrane permeabilizers and cell-penetrating peptides work; and 3) what are the underlying energetic factors and forces that are behind the Hofmeister series. In addition, second harmonic microscopy for time-resolved imaging of molecular transport through membranes and molecular intake into cells is to be developed. This project aims to provide enhanced understanding of a range of problems related to life processes. For example, though much is known about how atomic cations transport through cell membranes, little is known about how molecular or membrane structure affects transport of small or medium size molecules. Moreover, the mechanism of action of membrane permeabilizers is unknown. In addition, the driving forces behind the century old Hofmeister effect are poorly understood. The proposed research seeks to make advances that impact a range of scientific areas including nonlinear optics, colloidal science, protein function, and cell membrane transport mechanism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The membrane of a biological cell serves as the first line of defense against exogenous molecules in the extracellular environment. Regardless of whether they are essential nutrients or overtly toxic compounds, all molecules must first transport through the membrane before they can enter the cell. Understanding the various mechanisms through which molecules cross the cell membrane is therefore of fundamental biological importance. These processes are equally significant for advancing pharmaceutical research, as the effectiveness of medicinal compounds hinges on their propensity to enter the cell and influence the target biochemistry. 

 

Aside from the relatively straightforward question of whether or not a molecule can be taken up by a cell, it is of far greater interest to isolate and quantify the specific physio-chemical interactions between the molecule and the cell membrane. What component(s) of the membrane does the molecule interact with? How quickly does the molecule cross the membrane? How does the structure of the membrane influence the transport? Can membrane permeability be affected by addition of external molecules (like a drug molecule)? What are the most important molecular properties that may have deterministic effects on membrane transport? These questions are experimentally non-trivial, primarily due to the relatively diminutive surface area of the membrane compared to the vast volume of the extracellular bulk. 

 

In the study that was supported by this grant, we have shown that the nonlinear optical technique, second harmonic light scattering (SHS) is an effective method for answering questions related to molecular transport at cell membranes. In simple experiments, using only one laser, a turn-key style Ti:sapphire laser (oscillator only), we can measure the transport rate of a particular molecule through the cell membrane of a particular type of biological cell within a short time. Such measurements can even be made for cells with multiple membranes: the rate of going through each membrane by the molecule under observations can be acquired in one single experiment. Furthermore, using SHS as an imaging modality, we can measure spatially resolved transport rates at the membrane of a single biological cell. In fact, we found that the transport rate varies greatly from one part of the cell membrane to the other.

 

Other key findings of our study: 

We demonstrate that molecular structure is critical for membrane transport. The well-known Gram-stain dye, crystal violet (CV) is unable to passively diffuse across a phospholipid membrane. This observation is in stark contrast to the structurally similar dye, malachite green (MG), which can readily cross phospholipid membranes. It was argued that the presence of a permanent dipole (which is present in MG but absent in CV) may be a critical determining factor for whether or not a molecule can passively diffuse across a membrane.

We have characterized the effect of external membrane absorbed molecules on membrane permeability. In one study we quantitatively determined the membrane-specific mechanism-of-action (MOA) of the antimicrobial compound, azithromycin (Azm) on bacteria. 

We have unraveled the century old practice for classification bacteria ? the Gram stain and have also found that the two different types of bacteria, Gram-positive and Gram-negative, have distinctly different molecular transport behavior. Based on this observation, we have developed a new protocol that is more effective and efficient than the Gram-stain assay for bacteria classification.

 

Overall, since 2015, we have published 10 peer-reviewed papers, two were selected as journal cover articles, and one book chapter. We have also filed a patent disclosure on the new Gram bacteria classification protocol based on Second Harmonic Light Scattering.
